_.title: Right to acquire freehold or long lease

_.text: A secure tenant has the right—
in the circumstances and subject to the conditions and exceptions stated in the following provisions of this Chapter.
The right to buy only arises after the secure tenant has been a secure tenant for a period of not less than three years or for periods amounting together to not less than three years; but—
The right to buy does not arise if the landlord is a housing association which either—
Subject to subsection (5) below, the right to buy—
—(l) The following provisions apply to the interpretation of "house", "flat", "dwelling-house" and "relevant time" when used in this Chapter.
A dwelling-house is a house if, and only if, it (or so much of it as does not consist of land included by virtue of section 50(2) of this Act) is a structure reasonably so called; so that—

_.title: Joint tenants and members of family occupying dwelling-house otherwise than as joint tenants

_.text: A secure tenant may, in his notice under section 5 claiming to exercise the right to buy, require that not more than three members of his family who are not joint tenants but occupy the dwelling-house as their only or principal home should share the right to buy with him ; but he may validly do so in the case of any such member only if—

_.title: Notice claiming exercise of right to buy

_.text: Where a secure tenant serves on the landlord a written notice claiming to exercise the right to buy, the landlord shall (unless the notice is withdrawn) serve on the tenant, within four weeks, or in a case falling within subsection (2) below, eight weeks, either—
The price payable for a dwelling-house on a conveyance or grant in pursuance of this Chapter is—
For a conveyance the assumptions are that—
For the grant of a lease the assumptions are that—
The persons mentioned in subsection (2) above are—
A person exercising the right to buy is entitled to a discount equal, subject to the following provisions of this section, to the following percentage of the price before discount, that is to say—

The period to be taken into account for the purposes of the discount is, subject to the following provisions of this section, the aggregate of the periods during which, before the service of the notice claiming to exercise the right to buy.—

A period shall be taken into account under subsection (5)(a) above whether or not the dwelling-house or the landlord was the same as at the time of the service of the notice claiming to exercise the right to buy, unless the landlord was then a body specified in subsection (1) or (2) of section 2 of this Act; but—
Subsections (5) to (8) above shall have effect as if—

_.title: Repayment of discount on early disposal of freehold or lease

_.text: A disposal falls within this subsection if it is—
The liability that may arise under the covenant required by subsection (1) above shall be a charge on the dwelling-house—
The bodies referred to in subsection (4)(b) above are—

_.title: Right to a mortgage-amount to be secured

_.text: The amount which a secure tenant exercising the right to a mortgage is entitled to leave outstanding, or have advanced to him, on the security of the dwelling-house is, subject to the limit imposed by this section, the aggregate of—

The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision for calculating the amount which is to be taken into account under this section as a person's available annual income and for specifying a factor appropriate to it; and the regulations —

_.title: Notice of purchase price and right to a mortgage

_.text: Where a secure tenant has claimed to exercise the right to buy and that right has been established (whether by the landlord's admission or otherwise) the landlord shall, as soon as practicable, serve on the tenant a notice describing the dwelling-house and stating—
The notice shall, for the purpose of showing how the price has been arrived at, state—
the discount to which the tenant is entitled, stating—
The notice shall also inform the tenant
and shall be accompanied by a form for use by the tenant in exercising the right to a mortgage.

_.title: Right of tenant to have value determined by district valuer

_.text: A tenant may require that value to be determined or, as the case may be, re-determined by a notice in writing served on the landlord not later than three months after the service on him of the notice under section 10 ; except that—
The relevant notice is—
As soon as practicable after the service on it of a notice under subsection (1) above the landlord or Housing Corporation shall serve on the tenant a notice in writing stating—

_.title: Change of secure tenant after notice claiming right to buy

_.text: Where, after a secure tenant (in this section referred to as "the former tenant") has given a notice claiming the right to buy, another person (in this section referred to as " the new tenant") becomes the secure tenant—

_.title: Change of landlord after notice claiming right to buy or right to a mortgage

_.text: Where the secure tenant of a dwelling-house (in this section referred to as " the former tenant ") dies or otherwise ceases to be a secure tenant of the dwelling-house, and thereupon a child of his who occupies the dwelling-house as his only or principal home (in this section referred to as " the new tenant ") becomes the secure tenant of the dwelling-house (whether under the same or under another secure tenancy), the landlord may, if it thinks fit, count the whole or part of any period qualifying under this section—

A period qualifies under this section if it is a period during which the new tenant, since reaching the age of sixteen, occupied as his only or principal home a dwelling-house of which a parent of his was the secure tenant or one of joint tenants under a secure tenancy, and either—

Where a secure tenant has claimed to exercise the right to buy and that right has been established, the landlord shall be bound, subject to the following provisions of this section, to make to the tenant—
A notice under subsection (2) above shall not be served earlier than whichever of the following is applicable, that is to say—
A tenant is entitled to defer completion if—
If, in pursuance of a notice under subsection (4)(c) above, the tenant deposits the sum of £100 with the landlord, then—

If the tenant has failed to pay the rent or any other payment due from him as a tenant for a period of four weeks after it has been lawfully demanded from him, then, while the whole or part of it remains outstanding—

_.title: Conveyance of freehold and grant of lease

_.text: A conveyance of the freehold executed in pursuance of this Chapter shall conform with Parts I and
of Schedule 2 to this Act and a grant of a lease so executed with Parts I and
of that Schedule; and Part IV of that Schedule applies in relation to certain charges.

_.title: Right to a mortgage-terms of mortgage deed

_.text: The deed by which a mortgage is effected in pursuance of this Chapter shall, unless otherwise agreed between the parties, conform with the following provisions—

_.title: Dwelling-houses in National Parks and areas of outstanding natural beauty,

_.text: The condition is that the person to whom the disposal is made (or, if it is made to more than one person, at least one of them) has, throughout the period of three years immediately preceding the application for consent, either—
or has had the one in part or parts of that period and the other in the remainder; but the region need not have been the same throughout the whole of the period.

If the Secretary of State or, where the landlord is a housing association, the Housing Corporation, consents, the limitation specified in subsection (2) above may be replaced by the following limitation, that is to say, that until the end of the period of ten years beginning with the conveyance or grant there will be no disposal falling within subsection (8) below unless—
A disposal falls within this subsection if it is—

whether the disposal is of the whole or part of the dwelling-house; but a disposal in pursuance of an order under section 24 of the Matrimonial Causes Act 1973 or under section 2 of the Inheritance (Provision for Family and Dependants) Act 1975 or a vesting in a person taking under a will or on an intestacy is not a disposal falling within this subsection.
A certificate under subsection (2) above—

_.title: Secretary of State's power to intervene

_.text: Where, in consequence of the exercise by a secure tenant of the right to a mortgage a landlord becomes a mortgagee of a dwelling-house whilst a notice under subsection (1) above is in force in relation to the landlord and to the dwelling-house, then, while the notice remains in force—

_.title: Power to repeal or amend local Acts

_.text: —(l) The Secretary of State may by order repeal or amend any provision of a local Act passed before this Act where it appears to him that the provision is inconsistent with any provision of this Chapter.
In this Chapter—

References in this Chapter to a secure tenancy or a secure tenant are, in relation to any time before the commencement of Chapter II, references to a tenancy which would have been a secure tenancy if Chapter II had then been in force or to a person who would then have been a secure tenant; and for the purpose of determining whether a person would have been a secure tenant and his tenancy a secure tenancy—

_.title: Security of Tenure and Rights of Secure Tenants

_.text: The landlord condition is that—
The bodies referred to in subsection (2) (a) above are—
Where a secure tenancy is a tenancy for a term certain and the tenant dies, the tenancy remains a secure tenancy until either—
Where a periodic tenancy arises by virtue of this section—
A person is qualified to succeed the tenant under a secure tenancy if he occupied the dwelling-house as his only or principal home at the time of the tenant's death and either—
Where there is more than one person qualified to succeed the tenant—
Where a secure tenancy is a periodic tenancy the tenant is a successor if—

but a tenant to whom the tenancy was assigned in pursuance of an order under section 24 of the Matrimonial Causes Act 1973 is a successor only if the other party to the marriage was himself a successor.

Where within six months of the coming to an end of a secure tenancy which is a periodic tenancy (in this subsection referred to as the former tenancy) the tenant becomes a tenant under another secure tenancy which is a periodic tenancy ; and—
A secure tenancy which is either—

The court shall not entertain proceedings for the possession of a dwelling-house let under a secure tenancy or for the termination of a secure tenancy, unless the landlord has served on the tenant a notice complying with the provisions of this section and, if the tenancy is a periodic tenancy—
If the secure tenancy is a periodic tenancy the notice

and the date specified in it must not be earlier than the date on which the tenancy could, apart from this Act, be brought to an end by notice to quit given by the landlord if the notice to quit were given on the same date as the notice under this section.
The court shall not make the order—

and similarly where, on the death of the tenant, a secure tenancy is vested or otherwise disposed of in the course of the administration of his estate.

_.text: In this Chapter " landlord authority " means—

or has had the one in part or parts of that period and the other in the remainder; but the region need not have been the same throughout the whole of the period.
A disposal falls within this subsection if it is—

whether the disposal is of the whole or part of the house; but a disposal in pursuance of an order under section 24 of the Matrimonial Causes Act 1973 or under section 2 of the Inheritance (Provision for Family and Dependants) Act 1975 or a vesting in a person taking under a will or on an intestacy is not a disposal falling within this subsection.

_.title: Power to commute transitional town development subsidy and payments to receiving authority

_.text: Where, under section 5 of the 1975 Act, transitional town development subsidy is payable to a sending authority for years later than the year 1979-80 the Secretary of State may, with the agreement of the sending authority and of the receiving authority, determine—
In this Part of this Act—
" local authority " means the council of a district or London borough, the Greater London Council, the Common Council of the City of London or the Council of the Isles of Scilly;
" new town corporation" means a development corporation (within the meaning of the New Towns Act 1965) or the Commission for the New Towns ;
" year " means any period of 12 months beginning on a 1st April;
" year of account" means the year for which any housing subsidy is or may be payable under this Part of this Act.

_.title: Houses in multiple occupation: revised penalties for certain offences

_.text: For section 90 of the 1957 Act (overcrowding in houses let in lodgings) there is substituted the following section—
Overcrowding in houses let in lodgings.

If it appears to a local authority, in the case of a house within their district which is occupied by persons who do not form a single household, that an excessive number of persons is being or is likely to be accommodated on the premises having regard to the rooms available, the local authority may serve on the occupier of the premises or on any person having the control and management thereof, or on both, a notice under this subsection (an " overcrowding notice ") complying with subsections (2) and (3) below and including either—
The requirement referred to in subsection (1)(a) is that the person on whom the overcrowding notice is served must refrain from—
knowingly permitting such number of persons to occupy the premises as sleeping accommodation that it is not possible, without—
to avoid persons of opposite sexes and over the age of 12 years (other than persons living together as husband and wife) occupying sleeping accommodation in the same room.
The requirement referred to in subsection (1)(b) is that the person on whom the overcrowding notice is served must refrain from—
knowingly permitting a new resident to occupy any part of the premises as sleeping accommodation if it is not possible, without—

both to permit the new resident to so occupy any part of the premises and avoid persons of opposite sexes and over the age of 12 years (other than persons living together as husband and wife) occupying sleeping accommodation in the same room.
Not less than seven days before serving an overcrowding notice, the local authority shall—

The local authority may from time to time serve on the occupier of premises in respect of which an overcrowding notice is in force, a notice requiring him to furnish them within 7 days with a statement in writing giving all or any of the following particulars, that is to say—
Any person aggrieved by an overcrowding notice may, within twenty-one days after the date of service of the notice, appeal to the county court and—

" the 1977 Act" means the Rent Act 1977.

but paragraph (c) above does not apply in relation to a protected or statutory tenancy if the landlord is under an obligation to carry out external decoration or to keep the exterior of the dwelling-house in repair.

_.title: Provisions as to consents required by section 81.

_.text: If any question arises whether the withholding of a consent required by virtue of section 81 above was unreasonable it is for the landlord to show that it was not; and in determining that question the court shall, in particular, have regard to the extent to which the improvement would be likely—
Where the tenant has applied in writing for a consent which is required by virtue of section 81 then—
Any failure by
Words repealed by

a protected tenant or a statutory tenant to satisfy any reasonable condition imposed by his landlord in giving consent to an improvement which the tenant proposes to make, or has made, shall be treated
Words repealed by

for the purposes of the 1977 Act as a breach by the tenant of an obligation of his tenancy or, as the case may be, of an obligation of the previous protected tenancy which is applicable to the statutory tenancy.

_.title: Exclusion of certain housing associations from Part III.

_.text: This Part of this Act does not apply in relation to a housing association which falls within paragraph (d) of section 15(3) of the 1977 Act (certain societies registered under the Industrial and Provident Societies Act 1965).

_.title: Interpretation and application of Part III.

_.text: In this Part of this Act any expression used
Words repealed by
in the 1977 Act has the same meaning as in
Words repealed by
that Act.

_.title: Jurisdiction of county court and rules of procedure.

_.text: The rules and directions may provide—

_.title: Discretion of court in certain proceedings for possession.

_.text: Where, under the terms of a rental purchase agreement, a person has been let into possession of a dwelling-house and, on the termination of the agreement or of his right to possession under it, proceedings are brought for the possession of the dwelling-house, the court may—
for such period or periods as the court thinks fit.

In this section “ ” means an agreement for the purchase of a dwelling-house (whether freehold or leasehold property) under which the whole or part of the purchase price is to be paid in three or more instalments and the completion of the purchase is deferred until the whole or a specified part of the purchase price has been paid.

_.title: Restriction on discretion of court in making orders for possession of land.

_.text: The restrictions in subsection (1) above do not apply if—

_.title: Displacement of residential occupiers by housing authority.

_.text: In section 42(1) of the Land Compensation Act 1973 (which requires an authority acquiring or redeveloping land to indemnify another authority against the cost of rehousing a person displaced by the acquisition or redevelopment but only if the displacing authority is not an authority having functions under Part V of the 1957 Act) after the words “ Housing Act 1957” (in paragraph (b)) there are inserted the words “ or (if they are such an authority) the land is acquired or redeveloped by them otherwise than in the discharge of those functions”.

_.title: Amendments of Leasehold Reform Act 1967 etc.

_.text: Sections 1, . . . 9, 16, 23, and 29 of, and Schedules 1 and 3 to, the Leasehold Reform Act 1967 and Schedule 8 to the 1974 Act are amended as shown in Schedule 21 to this Act.

Section 20(1) of the Landlord and Tenant Act 1927 (apportionment of certain rents and other payments) has effect as respects applications for apportionment made under that section after the passing of this Act with the substitution in the proviso of “£5” for “two pounds”.
After section 20(1) of the said Act there is inserted the following subsection—

_.title: Rent assessment panels : pensions for presidents and vice-presidents.

_.title: Amendments, savings, transitional provisions and repeals.
